Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Impacts of an Extreme Flood on River Channel Formation and Riparian Forests

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will address the complex ways in which extreme floods impact river channel formation and stability and the structure and composition of related riparian forests. Previous studies of flood effects on river systems have focused on the history and causes of the flood, and their hydrology, with little attention to the flood impacts on riparian forest structure and the consequences of woody debris inputs on channel stability. Furthermore, the few studies that do exist have been limited to mountainous or arid regions, and their findings of limited applicability in more humid settings. More studies examining the variation of flood disturbances among different regions and within watersheds are needed to evaluate the long-term influence of floods on channel form, sediment, and forest structure, and to help predict how flood impacts can be managed in the future. The results of this study will help address U.S. Forest Service concerns over future impacts of increased flooding trends on federal facilities and the natural resources of national forests. The findings of this study will be shared during a workshop with the U.S. Forest Service, Department of Transportation, and surrounding communities. Besides benefits for natural resource management, this project will provide educational opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students in fieldwork and data analysis through the Ozarks Environmental and Water Resources Institute (OEWRI) at Missouri State University.

The goal of this project is to describe and analyze how an extreme flood (greater than a 100-year return interval) has contributed to riparian forest mortality and wood recruitment along the river channel, and to identify which variables are responsible for the spatial variations in those effects. The research plan addresses five questions: (1) Was riparian tree mortality systematically related to biological variables (e.g., species, size of trees, pre-flood wood patterns)?; (2) Was mortality systematically related to hydro-geomorphic variables (e.g., valley morphology, landform, flow depth)?; (3) How much woody debris was generated and what tree or site characteristics affected the likelihood of wood transportation versus accumulation?; (4) Do forest disturbance and wood debris patterns vary with scale at different sites along a gradient of increasing drainage area?; and (5) Can aerial imagery from drones/UAVs and photogrammetry-based analysis be used to acquire accurate quantitative data regarding tree mortality and wood accumulation? This study combines field research with imagery analysis to evaluate the effects of the largest flood on record on the North Fork River in the Missouri Ozarks. The results will be combined with those from other regional studies to develop a conceptual model of geomorphic-biotic response to extreme floods in a humid forest environment. While this study focuses on the assessment of immediate effects, it will offer insights into the spatial variability of those effects and the direction of recovery which can be monitored over the next decade or longer to gain a full understanding of the recovery process. The research will inform fundamental understanding of fluvial geomorphic and biogeographic processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
What are the impacts of catastrophic floods on channels and riparian forests in the Ozark Highlands? A large flood (>500-year recurrence interval) occurred in April-May 2017 in the North Fork of the White River watershed in the Ozarks Highlands of Missouri damaging buildings, roads, and bridges. This study quantifies flood-related channel changes and riparian forest damage at six tributary sites to better understand the role that channel and floodplain form and hydrology plays in controlling: (i) amount and distribution of riparian tree damage, (ii) supply and accumulation of large woody debris (LWD), and (iii) structure and composition of tree mortality. To test a relatively technique, low altitude, high-resolution (<3 in) aerial drone imagery was used to assess individual down and standing trees.

Riparian forest damage. Channel changes and riparian forest damage were measured from digitized drone imagery and verified through field surveys at six sites ranging from 165 to 2,780 ft in length and 188 to 422 ft in width. Overall, >1,000 trees were damaged by the flood at these sites and canopy cover was reduced by 8 to 63%. The volume of down trees ranged from 3 to 17 yd3/ac with the largest losses along the inside of channel bends and adjacent floodplains. However, wood accumulation after the flood was highest along the outside of channel bends and in back-swamp or chute features where flood energy was dissipated.  Overall, riparian forest damage increased downstream with drainage area and in locations where flood energy was enhanced by channel and valley features. 

Flood effects on forest structure and composition. More than 500 living and dead trees were sampled within 27 quadrants on transects across the valley bottoms of five tributaries. We found that over a quarter of the trees were killed, with mortality extending to terraces and valley walls that were high above the zones usually affected by floods. Differential mortality among species altered the forest composition, with mature stems of blackgum, hornbeam, red cedar, river birch and shortleaf pine all losing more than 30%, while other common species like white ash and black walnut had no losses. Overall, this extreme event had a significant impact on the density and composition of the riparian forest, even on landforms typically unaffected by floods.

Recruitment and distribution of large woody debris.  The accumulation of LWD such as whole trees, branches, trunks, and rootwads along stream beds and banks provides structural and habitat benefits to the channel system.  In the absence of pre-event data, we compared our post flood wood loads to results reported by two previous LWD studies in the Ozarks Highlands which did not specifically assess large flood impacts. We found that: 1) LWD loads in the present study were composed of a higher proportion of individual LWD pieces, rather than clustered within wood jams; 2) post-flood wood counts were significantly higher than found in the previous studies; and 3) amounts of flood-related LWD of young age increased exponentially with flood magnitude for the six sites.

Drone imaging methods and applications for assessing riparian forest damage. This project used inexpensive and off-the-shelf aerial drone systems to acquire photographic images to construct high accuracy 3-D elevation maps of the landscape using structure from motion photogrammetry.  The 3-D products included point clouds, digital surface models, and orthorectified aerial imagery with accuracies <4 in.  These products provided both base maps for channel and forest assessments and the data necessary to perform accurate two-dimensional (length and area) and 3-D (height) analysis of stream and riparian features. Our findings indicate that multiple flight lines of oblique photography (i.e., camera pointing sideways, not straight down) yield the most accurate 3-D products.  Furthermore, the gradual selection process, which filters out noisy and erroneous data during post-processing, can improve the overall quality of the final products and result in a significant reduction in the time required to process the data.

Conclusions. In the Ozark Highlands, large floods can damage riparian forests and the degree of damage may be predictable based on standard flood energy calculations and maps of the types and locations of valley landforms. Further, large floods provide an important supply of LWD to streams which is then redistributed naturally by moderate floods to provide ecological benefits. In general, drone imagery can accurately assess flood-related riparian forest damage. However, more research on the causes and effects of errors is needed before a standard protocol can be developed.  Our results suggest that as once-rare high-magnitude floods become more common, the composition and structure of temperate riparian forests are likely to change in response.
